lines.content: AI was used as a discussion tool to explore how responsibilities could be better separated across classes. It helped me think through design decisions and validate whether my refactoring aligned with OOP principles.
Outcome: Improved class structure and clearer separation of concerns after manual refactoring.
AI was used to cross-check my code against common coding standard practices (e.g., naming conventions, method length, formatting). It highlighted areas that might reduce readability.
Outcome: Code formatting and naming became more consistent after manual adjustments.
AI assisted in reviewing whether my JavaDoc comments were clear and meaningful. It helped suggest improvements in phrasing while ensuring comments described intent rather than restating code.
Outcome: Documentation became clearer and more aligned with good commenting practices.
AI was used to identify potential code problems such as duplication or overly complex logic. It prompted me to reconsider certain implementations and refactor where necessary.
Outcome: Code became cleaner and easier to maintain after applying improvements thoughtfully.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
-Usage of ChatGPT for adherence towards JavaDoc documentation standards.
-Usage of ChatGPT for suggestions towards code refactoring into different classes for A-MoreOOP.
-Core logic, structure, and error messages remain my own implementation.

YXBot is a task manager chatbot that allows you to manage tasks efficiently using simple commands.
- Java 17 or above must be installed on your computer.
- Ensure `java` is available in your system PATH.
- Open a terminal (Command Prompt / PowerShell / Terminal).
- Navigate to the folder containing the JAR file.
- The YXBot GUI window will launch.
Displays all tasks in the list.
Adds a task with a deadline.
Adds a task with start and end time.
event DESCRIPTION /from yyyy-MM-dd HHmm /to yyyy-MM-dd HHmm
- End time must be after start time.
Marks a task as not done.
- Tasks are automatically saved after modifications.
- Invalid input will show an error message.
* Represents a command parsed from user input.
* Contains the command type and any associated data needed for execution.
* Serves as the base class for specific command implementations.
* Constructs a Command with only a type (for commands with no additional data).
* @param type The type of command (e.g., BYE, LIST)
* Constructs a Command that operates on a specific task by index.
* @param type The type of command (e.g., MARK, UNMARK, DELETE)
* @param index The 0-based index of the task to operate on
* Constructs a Command that adds a new task.
* @param type The type of command (e.g., TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT)
* @param task The task to be added
* Constructs a Command that searches for tasks.
* Executes the command. Base implementation throws an exception as this method
* should be overridden by specific command subclasses.
* @param tasks The task list to operate on
* @param ui The user interface for displaying results
* @param storage The storage handler for persisting changes
* @throws YXBotException If command execution fails or method is not overridden
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws YXBotException {
throw new YXBotException("Execute method must be overridden");
* Enumeration of all possible command types in YXBot.
* Each constant represents a specific user command that can be parsed and executed.

* This exception stops the program to prevent data loss.
* Constructs a new CorruptedDataException with the specified detail message.
* @param message The detail message explaining the data corruption
* Represents a task with a deadline.
* A Deadline task has a description and a specific date/time by which it must be completed.
* Constructs a new Deadline task with the specified description and due date.
* @param description The description of the deadline task
* @param by The due date and time in "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm" format
* @throws DateTimeParseException If the date string cannot be parsed
public Deadline(String description, String by) throws DateTimeParseException {
* Returns the string representation of the deadline task for display.
* Format: [D][status] description (by: MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a)
* @return Formatted string showing task type, status, description, and deadline
* Returns the file format representation of the deadline task for storage.
* Format: D | status | description | yyyy-MM-dd HHmm
* @return String formatted for saving to data file
* Compares this deadline task to another object for equality.
* Two deadline tasks are equal if they have the same description, status, and due date.
* @param other The object to compare with
* @return true if the objects are equal, false otherwise
* Returns a hash code for this deadline task.
* @return A hash code based on the task's class, description, and due date

public static DialogBox getYxbotDialog(String text, Image img) {
super("This task already exists in your list.");
* Represents an event task with a start and end time.
* An Event task has a description and specific date/time range during which it occurs.
* Constructs a new Event task with the specified description, start time, and end time.
* @param description The description of the event
* @param from The start date and time in "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm" format
* @param to The end date and time in "yyyy-MM-dd HHmm" format
* @throws DateTimeParseException If either date string cannot be parsed
public Event(String description, String from, String to) throws DateTimeParseException {
* Returns the string representation of the event task for display.
* Format: [E][status] description (from: MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a to: MMM dd yyyy, h:mm a)
* @return Formatted string showing task type, status, description, and time range
* Returns the file format representation of the event task for storage.
* Format: E | status | description | yyyy-MM-dd HHmm | yyyy-MM-dd HHmm
* @return String formatted for saving to data file
* Compares this event task to another object for equality.
* Two event tasks are equal if they have the same description, status, start time, and end time.
* @param other The object to compare with
* @return true if the objects are equal, false otherwise
* Returns a hash code for this event task.
* @return A hash code based on the task's class, description, start time, and end time
* Represents a command to find tasks containing a specific keyword in their description.
* This command searches through all tasks in the task list and displays those that
* contain the given keyword in a case-insensitive manner.
* Constructs a FindCommand with the specified keyword to search for.
* @param keyword The keyword to search for in task descriptions
* Executes the find command by searching through all tasks in the task list
* for those whose description contains the specified keyword.
* Displays matching tasks with numbering, or a message if no tasks are found.
* @param tasks   The task list containing all tasks to search through
* @param ui      The user interface for displaying results
* @param storage The storage handler (not used in this command)
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) {
assert tasks != null : "TaskList cannot be null";
assert ui != null : "UI cannot be null";
"Search keyword cannot be null or empty";

* Thrown when a deadline command has invalid format.
* Constructs a new InvalidDeadlineFormatException with a default message.
* Thrown when a delete command has invalid format.
* Example: "delete" (missing task number) or "delete abc" (non-numeric task number)
* Constructs a new InvalidDeleteFormatException with a default message.
super("Missing task number! Correct format: delete [task number]");
* Thrown when an event command has invalid format.
* Example: "event task" (missing /from or /to) or incorrect order of parameters
* Constructs a new InvalidEventFormatException with a default message.
super("Event end time must be after start time.");
* Thrown when a mark command has invalid format.
* Example: "mark" (missing task number) or "mark abc" (non-numeric task number)
* Constructs a new InvalidMarkFormatException with a default message.
super("Missing task number! Correct format: mark [task number]");
* Thrown when a task number is out of valid range.
* Example: "mark 0" or "mark 10" when only 5 tasks exist
* Constructs a new InvalidTaskNumberException with a default message.
* Thrown when a todo command has invalid format.
* Constructs a new InvalidTodoFormatException with a default message.
* Thrown when an unmark command has invalid format.
* Example: "unmark" (missing task number) or "unmark abc" (non-numeric task number)
* Constructs a new InvalidUnmarkFormatException with a default message.
super("Missing task number! Correct format: unmark [task number]");
